Question:
\[
\newcommand{\V}{V}
\]

{\large\bf Problem}

Six villages are situated at the vertices  
\[
\V_0,\;\V_1,\;\V_2,\;\V_3,\;\V_4,\;\V_5
\]
of a regular hexagon, listed in clockwise order.  
Every pair of distinct vertices is joined by a straight path, so that the
$\binom{6}{2}=15$ segments form a complete graph inscribed in the hexagon.
These segments cross in exactly $13$ interior points, one of which is the
center of the hexagon.

Fix two distinct vertices $\V_i$ (the \emph{start}) and $\V_j$ (the
\emph{destination}).  
A \emph{monotone route} from $\V_i$ to $\V_j$ is a polygonal path that

\begin{itemize}
    \item is contained entirely in the union of the $15$ straight segments,
    \item starts at $\V_i$ and ends at $\V_j$,
    \item turns only at the $6$ vertices or at the $13$ interior
          intersection points, and
    \item is \emph{strictly approaching} $\V_j$:   
          every point reached on the route is closer to $\V_j$
          (in the usual Euclidean distance) than the point immediately
          preceding it.
\end{itemize}

Beginning on April $1$, three travelers all depart from $\V_0$ but head for
different destinations:
the first toward $\V_1$, the second toward $\V_2$, and the third toward
$\V_3$ (the first, second, and third clockwise vertices after $\V_0$,
respectively).  
Each traveler walks exactly one monotone route per day and must eventually
use \emph{every} monotone route from $\V_0$ to his own destination.  
The wedding of a traveler is held on the calendar day immediately
following the day on which he completes his final required route.

Determine the three wedding dates in the month of April.

\medskip
\noindent
{\bf Bonus.}  
If the island’s coastline (the circumcircle of the hexagon) is
$10$ miles long, what is the length (in miles) of the longest monotone route
taken by any of the three travelers?
Hint: To find the number of routes, start from the son's village and move to the farthest away village or crossing from the bride's village he could travel to that hasn't been visited.  Record the number of routes to this village or crossing.  Keep repeating this, marking the number of routes to each village or crossing along the path until reaching his destination.
Human Solution:
The wedding dates are April 6th, May 12th, and August 1st.
Bonus question: ~ 6.86 miles.
All villages are crossings.  Here are the steps to determine the number of routes to reach any point:
1) First set the starting point to one.
2) Select the unvisited crossing that is adjacent to a visited crossing and is closer to the destination, but which is the farthest such unvisited crossing from the destination.
3) Set this crossing to the sum of the values for all of the adjacent visited crossings.  (If you do this in the correct order, all the adjacent visited crossings are farther from the destination.)
4) If the last selected crossing is not the destination then continue with step two.
Which points are closer or farther from the destination can be determined using the right triangles formed by the intersecting paths.  The shortest path from a point to a line is perpendicular to the line.  Moving toward the right angle formed by the path and the line is moving closer to the point; moving away from this right angle is moving farther from the point.
Note that when moving from a village to the opposite village that all of the crossings to the left of the direct path between the villages are symmetrical with the corresponding crossing to the right.
The routes:
This is a little hard to follow without a diagram, so you might want to create one.  The diagram is a regular hexagon with lines connecting each pair of vertices.  There are three intersections created along each of these connecting lines, with the three lines connecting opposite vertices meeting in the middle.  Label one vertex A and moving clockwise, label the remaining vertices B-F.  Label the middle intersection M.  Label the intersection along the path from A to M (path AM) as Ai; label the similar intersections for the remaining vertices as Bi to Fi.  Label the intersection of paths AC and BF as ABi.  Label the similar intersections BCi, CDi, DEi, EFi and FAi.
Routes to an adjacent village (A to B):
To determine the routes from A to B first set A to 1.
The farthest point from B that is closer than A and adjacent to A is Ai.  Ai can only be reached from A, so set Ai to 1.
The next farthest point is ABi.  ABi can be reached from A and Ai so set ABi to 1+1=2.
The next farthest point is Bi.  Bi can only be reached from ABi, so set Bi to 2.
The next farthest point is the destination B.  B can be reached from A, ABi and Bi, so set B to 1+2+2=5.
There are five routes to an adjacent village, so that son will make his last trip on April 5th and the wedding will be the next day on April 6th.
Routes to the second village along the coast (A to C):
A = 1
AFi = A = 1
Fi = AFi = 1
Ai = A + AFi = 2
ABi = Ai + A = 3
M and B are equidistant from C, so in either order:
M = Ai + Fi = 3
B = A + ABi = 4
Bi and Di are equidistant from C, so in either order:
Bi = B + ABi + M = 10
Di = M = 3
BCi and CDi are equidistant from C, so in either order:
BCi = B + Bi = 14
CDi = Di = 3
Ci = BCi + CDi + M = 20
C = B + BCi + CDi + Ci = 41
There are 41 routes from A to C, so that son will make his last trip on May 11th and the wedding will be the next day on May 12th.
Routes to the opposite village (A to D):
Since the intersections to the left and right of the direct path are mirrors, the left-side calculation is assigned to both.
A = 1
F, B = A = 1
FAi, ABi = A + B = 2
Ai = A + ABi + FAi = 5
Fi, Bi = ABi + B = 3
EFi, BCi = B + Bi = 4
M, C and E are equidistant from D, so in any order:
M = Ai + Fi + Bi = 11
E, C = B + BCi = 5
Ei, Ci = BCi + M + C = 20
DEi, CDi = C + Ci = 25
Di = M + CDi + DEi = 61
D = C + E + CDi + DEi + Di = 121
There are 121 routes from A to D, so that son will make his last trip on July 31st and the wedding will be the next day on August 1st.
Bonus Question:
The longest route is a route to the opposite village.  Given the above diagram, the longest routes the son will have to travel from A to D is:
A-B-ABi-C-Ci-CDi-Di-D
and the mirror route
A-F-FAi-E-Ei-DEi-Di-D
(ABi-C is the same as ABi-Bi-BCi-C)
If the circumference is 10 miles then the diameter is 10/Pi miles and the radius is 5/Pi miles.  Since a regular hexagon is formed from six equilateral triangles, the length of a side of the hexagon is equal to its radius.
The path A-B is then 5/Pi miles.  The path B-D bisects the path C-M, so both C-Ci and Di-D are half the radius.  A-B + C-Ci + Di-D is then equal to the diameter 10/Pi.
The paths B-ABi, ABi-BCi, and BCi-C are all sides of equilateral triangles with a height of one half of the radius.  The paths Ci-CDi and CDi-Di are each half of the side of one of these same triangles.  The side of one of these equilateral triangles is
5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)
So the total distance traveled is
10/Pi + 4*(5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)) = 10/Pi + 20/(sqrt(3)*Pi) ~ 6.86 miles

FAi, ABi = A + B = 2
Ai = A + ABi + FAi = 5
Fi, Bi = ABi + B = 3
EFi, BCi = B + Bi = 4
M, C and E are equidistant from D, so in any order:
M = Ai + Fi + Bi = 11
E, C = B + BCi = 5
Ei, Ci = BCi + M + C = 20
DEi, CDi = C + Ci = 25
Di = M + CDi + DEi = 61
D = C + E + CDi + DEi + Di = 121
There are 121 routes from A to D, so that son will make his last trip on July 31st and the wedding will be the next day on August 1st.
Bonus Question:
The longest route is a route to the opposite village.  Given the above diagram, the longest routes the son will have to travel from A to D is:
A-B-ABi-C-Ci-CDi-Di-D
and the mirror route
A-F-FAi-E-Ei-DEi-Di-D
(ABi-C is the same as ABi-Bi-BCi-C)
If the circumference is 10 miles then the diameter is 10/Pi miles and the radius is 5/Pi miles.  Since a regular hexagon is formed from six equilateral triangles, the length of a side of the hexagon is equal to its radius.
The path A-B is then 5/Pi miles.  The path B-D bisects the path C-M, so both C-Ci and Di-D are half the radius.  A-B + C-Ci + Di-D is then equal to the diameter 10/Pi.
The paths B-ABi, ABi-BCi, and BCi-C are all sides of equilateral triangles with a height of one half of the radius.  The paths Ci-CDi and CDi-Di are each half of the side of one of these same triangles.  The side of one of these equilateral triangles is
5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)
So the total distance traveled is
10/Pi + 4*(5/(sqrt(3)*Pi)) = 10/Pi + 20/(sqrt(3)*Pi) ~ 6.86 miles

Question:
Let $N$ be a positive integer expressed in base $10$ with leftmost digit $d$ and remaining part $r$ (which may include leading zeros), so that  
\[
N = d\cdot 10^{k} + r,
\]
where $1\le d\le 9$ and $k\ge 1$ is the number of digits of $r$.  
Define
\[
M = 10r + d,
\]
the integer obtained by moving the first digit of $N$ to the right end of the number (i.e., rotating $N$ to the left once).

Determine the least positive integer $N$ such that  
\[
M = \frac{3}{2}\,N.
\]
Hint: The number has 16 digits.  I repeat, the number has 16 digits.
Human Solution:
1,176,470,588,235,294
x 1.5 =
1,764,705,882,352,941
Here's how you find the number:
You needed to find a repeating fraction such that the number of repeating digits is one less than the number. This would be a prime number, and seven is the lowest number with this property. With this property, every digit in the repeating fraction appears in each place exactly once (i.e., every repeated digit appears as the first digit after the decimal exactly once for n/p where p > n > 0).
Now you need to find any occurrences where the nth digit is followed by the 1.5nth digit.  'n' will obviously be even.
The repeating digits in 1/7 and their corresponding 'n' where the digits are the first digit after the decimal point are:
142857 - repeating digits
132645 - n
The ordered pairs of adjacent values of n are (1,3), (3,2), (2,6), (6,4), (4,5) and (5,1).  None of these has the second number equal to one and a half times the first number.
The next prime number p with a repeating fraction for 1/p containing p-1 repeating digits is 17.  The repeating digits for 1/17 are:
.0588235294117647
The easiest way to assign 'n' for each digit is to list all of the digit pairs in order:
XX - n (digit)
05 - 1 (1)
11 - 2 (11)
17 - 3 (12)
23 - 4 (5)
29 - 5 (8)
35 - 6 (6)
41 - 7 (10)
47 - 8 (15)
52 - 9 (7)
58 - 10 (2)
64 - 11 (14)
70 - 12 (16)
76 - 13 (13)
82 - 14 (4)
88 - 15 (3)
94 - 16 (9)
Checking the even-numbered values of n in the above table reveals that ALL even values of n less than 2/3 of 17 are followed by the 1.5n digit.  The values of n are and their digit places are:
2,3 (11,12)
4,6 (5,6)
6,9 (6,7)
8,12 (15,16)
10,15 (2,3)
So the five smallest numbers with this property are:
1176470588235294
2352941176470588
3529411764705882
4705882352941176
5882352941176470
Notice that 2352941176470588 can be rotated TWICE, yielding 1.5 times the number each time since the 4->6->9 n digits are in order.

Okay, so I have this problem where I need to find the least positive integer N such that when I move its first digit to the end, the new number M is equal to (3/2) times N. Hmm, that sounds interesting. Let me try to break it down step by step.

First, let me understand the problem statement again. N is a positive integer in base 10. It has a leftmost digit d, and the remaining part is r, which could have leading zeros. So, N can be expressed as d multiplied by 10^k plus r, where k is the number of digits in r. That makes sense because if r has k digits, shifting d by k places would place it correctly.

Then, M is defined as 10 times r plus d. So, M is the number obtained by moving the first digit d to the end of r. For example, if N is 1234, then d is 1, r is 234, and M would be 2341.

The condition given is that M equals (3/2) times N. So, mathematically, that's:

10r + d = (3/2)(d*10^k + r)

I need to find the smallest such N. Alright, let's write that equation down and see if I can manipulate it to find N.

Starting with:

10r + d = (3/2)(d*10^k + r)

Let me multiply both sides by 2 to eliminate the fraction:

2*(10r + d) = 3*(d*10^k + r)

Expanding both sides:

20r + 2d = 3d*10^k + 3r

Now, let's bring all terms to one side:

20r + 2d - 3d*10^k - 3r = 0

Simplify the terms:

(20r - 3r) + (2d - 3d*10^k) = 0

17r + 2d - 3d*10^k = 0

Hmm, so:

17r = 3d*10^k - 2d

Factor out d on the right side:

17r = d*(3*10^k - 2)

So, r = [d*(3*10^k - 2)] / 17

Since r must be an integer (as it's part of the number N), the right-hand side must be an integer. Therefore, [d*(3*10^k - 2)] must be divisible by 17.

So, 17 divides d*(3*10^k - 2). Since d is a digit from 1 to 9, and 17 is a prime number, 17 must divide (3*10^k - 2) or 17 must divide d. But d is between 1 and 9, and 17 is larger than 9, so 17 cannot divide d. Therefore, 17 must divide (3*10^k - 2).

So, 3*10^k ≡ 2 mod 17

We can write this as:

3*10^k ≡ 2 mod 17

Let me solve for k here. So, 10^k ≡ (2/3) mod 17. But division in modular arithmetic is multiplication by the inverse. So, 2/3 mod 17 is equivalent to 2*(3^{-1}) mod 17.

First, find the inverse of 3 modulo 17. That is, find a number x such that 3x ≡ 1 mod 17.

Testing x=6: 3*6=18≡1 mod17. Yes, so 3^{-1} is 6 mod17.

Therefore, 10^k ≡ 2*6 ≡12 mod17.

So, 10^k ≡12 mod17.

Now, I need to find the smallest k such that 10^k ≡12 mod17.

Let me compute 10^k mod17 for k=1,2,3,... until I get 12.

Compute:

k=1: 10^1=10 mod17=10

k=2: 10^2=100 mod17. 17*5=85, 100-85=15. So, 15.

k=3: 10^3=10*15=150 mod17. 17*8=136, 150-136=14.

k=5: 10^5=10*4=40 mod17. 17*2=34, 40-34=6.

k=6: 10^6=10*6=60 mod17. 17*3=51, 60-51=9.

k=7: 10^7=10*9=90 mod17. 17*5=85, 90-85=5.

k=8: 10^8=10*5=50 mod17. 17*2=34, 50-34=16.

k=9: 10^9=10*16=160 mod17. 17*9=153, 160-153=7.

k=10:10^10=10*7=70 mod17. 17*4=68, 70-68=2.

k=11:10^11=10*2=20 mod17=3.

k=12:10^12=10*3=30 mod17=13.

k=13:10^13=10*13=130 mod17. 17*7=119, 130-119=11.

k=14:10^14=10*11=110 mod17. 17*6=102, 110-102=8.

k=15:10^15=10*8=80 mod17. 17*4=68, 80-68=12.

Ah, finally at k=15, 10^15 ≡12 mod17.

So, the smallest k satisfying 10^k ≡12 mod17 is k=15.

Therefore, k=15.

So, now, going back, we have:

r = [d*(3*10^15 - 2)] /17

Since r must be a k-digit number, which is 15 digits in this case, but wait, hold on. Wait, k is the number of digits in r, right? So, if k=15, then r is a 15-digit number. But N is d followed by r, so N has 1 + 15 = 16 digits.

But wait, let me confirm: N = d*10^k + r, where k is the number of digits in r. So, if r has k digits, then N has k+1 digits. So, in this case, k=15, so N has 16 digits.

r = [d*(3*10^15 - 2)] /17

We need r to be an integer, so [d*(3*10^15 - 2)] must be divisible by 17. But since we already have 3*10^15 ≡2 mod17, as 10^15≡12 mod17, so 3*12=36≡36-2*17=36-34=2 mod17. So, 3*10^15 -2 ≡0 mod17, so yes, it's divisible by17.

Question:
Let $N=\overline{abcdef}$ be a $6$-digit integer written in base $10$ whose digits $a,b,c,d,e,f$ are pairwise distinct and with $a\neq0$.  Define the following five related integers.  

• $N_1$ is obtained from $N$ by rotating its digits one place to the left: $N_1=\overline{bcdefa}$.  
• $N_2$ is obtained from $N$ by rotating its digits one place to the right: $N_2=\overline{fabcde}$.  
• $N_3$ is obtained from $N$ by swapping its first three and last three digits: $N_3=\overline{defabc}$.  
• $N_4$ is obtained by grouping the digits of $N$ into the three blocks $\overline{ab},\overline{cd},\overline{ef}$ and then rotating these blocks one place to the left: $N_4=\overline{cdefab}$.  
• $N_5$ is obtained by rotating those same two-digit blocks one place to the right: $N_5=\overline{efabcd}$.

Let 
\[
T = N + N_1 + N_2 + N_3 + N_4 + N_5.
\]

The integer $N$ satisfies all of the following conditions:

1.  $\displaystyle a+b+c+d+e+f \;=\; \overline{ef};$  
2.  $\displaystyle a+b \;=\; e+f;$  
3.  the first and last digits of $T$ are exactly $e$ and $f$ (in either order);  
4.  each of the two-digit numbers $\overline{ab},\ \overline{cd},\ \overline{ef}$ is prime.

Determine $N$.
Human Solution:
416723
Here's how Rex determined Ralph's number:
The insight Rex needed to solve this involves the number produced by the sum of the six numbers created from configurations of the digits in the number. Assign ABCDEF to the digits in Ralph's number. The six numbers Ralph had Rex add together were:
ABCDEF
BCDEFA
FABCDE
DEFABC
CDEFAB
EFABCD
Notice that the six digits in each column in this summation are the six digits in the number. This means that the sum of each column will be the digital sum of the number. If that digital sum is represented by A+B+C+D+E+F = XY, then the problem is equivalent to adding:
XXXXXX0
+YYYYYY
The first and last digits will be X and Y only if 10 > X + Y. If X + Y is greater than 9, then the first digit will be X+1. Since both the digital sum of the number (A+B+C+D+E+F) and the first and last digit of the sum of the numbers match the digits XY, you know that 10 > X + Y. When Rex realized this relation he smiled because he knew that he had enough information now.
The digital sum of the number must be between 0+1+2+3+4+5 = 15 and 9+8+7+6+5+4 = 39. Since each of the digit pairs in the number form a prime number, the digital sum must be a prime number in this range. There are only six prime numbers in this range: 17, 19, 23, 29, 31, and 37. 19, 29 and 37 are eliminated since 1+9 > 9, 2+9 > 9 and 3+7 > 9.
The sum of the first two digits must match the sum of the last two digits (X+Y). For 31, 3+1=4, but the only other way to make four without repeating any digits is 0+4. Zero and four can't form a prime number, so the digital sum can't be 31. This leaves 17 and 23.
For the digital sum to be 17, the digits must be either 0+1+2+3+4+7 = 17 or 0+1+2+3+5+6 = 17. Only 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 7 has both a 1 and 7 to make the last two digits be 17. However, there is no pair of remaining digits with a sum of 1+7 = 8, so the digital sum can't be 17 and therefore must be 23.
If the last two digits are 23, then the first two digits must total 2+3 = 5. The possibilities are 0+5 = 5 and 1+4 = 5. There is one prime number possible with each of these pairs: 05 and 41. The first two digits of the number can't be 05 because then the number would be a 5-digit number and Ralph's number has six digits. So the first two digits are 41 and the last two digits are 23.
Since the sum of all the digits is 23, then the sum of the middle two digits must be 23 - (2+3) - (4+1) = 13. There are two pairs of the remaining digits that total 13: 5+8 = 13, and 6+7 = 13. Sixty-seven is the only prime number that can be formed from these pairs, so the middle two digits are 67 and Ralph's number is 416723.

Question:
\[
\textbf{Problem.}
\]

A piece of property is the shape of a regular \(n\)-gon whose side length is \(L\) feet.  
Centered on the lot is a smaller, similar, regular \(n\)-gon house whose sides are each tangent to a circular concrete foundation of radius \(r\) feet.

\begin{itemize}
    \item The shortest distance from the foundation’s circumference to the boundary of the lot is exactly \(2r\) feet.
    \item A circular atrium of diameter equal to \(\dfrac1{10}\) of the lot’s \emph{diameter}\footnote{The diameter of the lot is the greatest possible distance between two points on its boundary.} is located at the center of the house.
    \item During excavation a straight section of pipe of length \(L\) feet was found passing through the center of the house; its endpoints lie on two (distinct) sides of the house, and the pipe divides the area of the house into two congruent regions.
    \item After construction the pipe was installed as a gate across one side of the lot, and fencing having total length \(400\text{ ft}\) was erected along the other \(n-1\) sides.
\end{itemize}

Determine, in square feet, the total area contained inside the exterior walls of the house (this area includes all walls, stairwells, hallways, etc.).
Hint:
A regular polygon has the length of all sides and arc of all interior angles equal.
The first thing you need to determine is the number of sides for Ralph's house.  The rest solves in a fairly straight-forward manner once this is determined.
Human Solution:
2,730 sq. feet
Rex realized that he would need to know the number of sides on Ralph's house in order to make use of the only measurement Ralph gave him, which was the perimeter minus the length of one side for the property.  The length of a side of the property needed to be the length of the pipe that bisected the area of the house.  The length of the pipe is the key to figuring out how many sides the house has.
The house is a regular polygon inscribed in the circle that is the foundation.  Since the closest edge of the property is equal to the diameter of the foundation, then the property must be a similar polygon circumscribed around a circle with a diameter three times the size of the foundation.
The minimum and maximum length line segments that can bisect the area of a regular polygon are calculated differently for even- and odd-sided polygons.
For an even-sided polygon inscribed in a circle of radius r, the maximum line segment has its ends at two opposite vertices and the length is 2r. The minimum line segment goes from the middle of one edge to the middle of the opposite edge.  The distance from the edge to the center of a polygon is the apothem, so the minimum line segment is two times the apothem a.
For an odd-sided polygon the maximum bisector goes from a vertex to the middle of the opposite side, so the maximum is r + a. As with an even-sided polygon, the minimum bisector for an odd-sided polygon extends through the center of the polygon and at an angle halfway between two adjacent maximum bisectors.
2Pi radians = 360 degrees.  The central angle between any two adjacent vertices on a polygon with n sides is then 2Pi/n and the angle between a vertex radius and the apothem is half that or Pi/n.  The apothem and the radius form two sides of a right triangle, with the third side formed by one half of the side bisected by the apothem.  For a regular polygon with n sides of length s this gives the following relationships:
a = r*Cos(Pi/n)

and the area of the two floors in Ralph's house is

Question:
For a positive integer $x$, let
\[
s(x)=\text{(sum of the decimal digits of }x),\qquad   
s^{(1)}(x)=s(x),\qquad   
s^{(k+1)}(x)=s\bigl(s^{(k)}(x)\bigr)\ (k\ge 1),
\]
and let  
$\operatorname{rev}(x)$ denote the integer obtained by reversing the decimal digits of $x$
(e.g. $\operatorname{rev}(247)=742$).

Find all positive integers $N$ that satisfy the following six conditions.

1. The sum of the prime factors of $N$ is 1400. 

2.  Both $N-1$ and $N+1$ are the product of exactly five (not necessarily distinct) primes.

3.  The union of the sets of prime divisors of $N-1$, $N$, and $N+1$ contains exactly $13$ distinct primes.

4.  For every prime $p\mid N$ the number $s(p)$ is prime.  
    If
    \[
      P=\prod_{p\mid N}s(p),
    \]
    then $s(P)$ is prime, $s(N)$ is prime, and
    \[
      s(N)=\operatorname{rev}\!\bigl(s(P)\bigr)\ne s(P).
    \]

5.  Write $N$ with $2m$ digits ($m\ge 2$) as
    \[
      N=d_1d_2\dots d_{2m}\quad(d_1\ne 0).
    \]
    Among the digits $d_1,\dots,d_{2m}$, the only prime digits (that is, digits $2,3,5,$ or $7$) are the two middle digits $d_m,d_{m+1}$, and the two-digit number $10d_m+d_{m+1}$ is prime.

6.  The three-digit integer $d_1d_2d_3$ is prime, and the three numbers
    \[
       s(d_1d_2d_3),\qquad s^{(2)}(d_1d_2d_3),\qquad s^{(3)}(d_1d_2d_3)
    \]
    are all prime.

It is known that exactly two integers satisfy Conditions 1–6, and that exactly one of these two integers is divisible by $13$.

(a) Determine the two integers satisfying Conditions 1–5.  
(b) Specify which of them is NOT divisible by $13$.
Hint:
You don't have to factor any numbers to find the answer, nor do you need to determine the primality of any numbers larger than 1000.
The problem is as much about logic as it is about math.
Human Solution:
The two numbers Ralph finds are 443,794 and 887,314.  Rex's number is 887,314.
887313 = 3 x 7 x 29 x 31 x 47
887314 = 2 x 487 x 911
887315 = 5 x 11 x 13 x 17 x 73
Here's how Ralph did it:
First, since the three adjacent numbers don't share any prime numbers, the middle number must be even, otherwise both the other numbers would have to be divisible by 2.  If one of the factors in Rex's number is two, then the other two factors must add up to 1400 - 2 = 1398.
The maximum product of two numbers that add up to 1398 is 699 x 699, so the upper bound for Rex's number is 2 x 699 x 699 = 977,202.
The product of the first ten odd prime numbers is
3 x 5 x 7 x 11 x 13 x 17 x 19 x 23 x 29 x 31 = 100,280,245,065
This is the minimum value for the product of Rex's number minus one times Rex's number plus one.  Therefore the square root of this number is the lower bound for Rex's number.  The square root of 100,280,245,065 ~ 316,670.  So now Ralph knows that Rex's number is an even number between 316,670 and 977,202.  He figures this could be found by brute force given the other clues.  (In fact, 887,314 is the only number in this range that is between two numbers with five or more unique prime factors, but Ralph doesn't know that.)
The digital sum of the prime factors of the number are prime numbers, one of which is 2.  The other two must be prime numbers between 316,670 / 1,398 ~ 227 and 1,398.  The maximum digital sum for numbers in this range is 3 x 9 = 27, so the maximum value for the product of the three prime digital sums is 2 x 23 x 23 = 1,058.  The digital sum of this number is also prime.  The maximum digital sum in this range is 27, so the digital sum of this product is a prime number less than 27.
The largest digital sum for a number in the range 316,670 to 977,202 is 6 x 9 = 54.  This means that the digital sum of the number must be a prime number less than 54 that is a different prime number less than 27 when reversed.  There are four prime numbers less than 54 that are a different prime number when reversed: 13, 17, 31 and 37.  The digital sum of Rex's number must be 31.
The middle two digits are prime.  For there to be a middle two digits, the number of digits in the number must be even.  So now the upper bound for the number is 977,202.  The number formed by the middle two digits must also be prime.  There are only four two-digit prime numbers composed of prime digits: 23, 37, 53 and 73.  The number formed by the first three digits is prime, so the third digit can't be 2 or 5.  The middle two digits must be either 37 or 73.
Since the sum of the first three digits is a prime number, the sum must be one of 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19 or 23.  Since the number must start with a 4, 6, 8 or 9, the minimum value for the first three digits is 403, which eliminates 5 as a digital sum.  The digital sum of the digital sum of the first three digits must be prime, so it can't be 13, 17 or 19.  This leaves 7, 11 or 23 as the digital sum of the first three digits.
Since the only possibility for the first three digits totaling 7 is 403, Ralph did a couple of quick calculations to determine that 403 = 13 x 31, so it isn't prime.  So the digital sum of the first three digits must be either 11 or 23 and the digital sum of the last three digits must be 20 or 8.
There are only four ways to make a digital sum of 11 for the first three digits that ends in a three or seven and starts with 4, 6, 8 or 9: 407, 443, 623 and 803.  Ralph does a couple more quick calculations and determines that 407 = 11 x 37, 623 = 7 x 89 and 803 = 11 x 73, but that 443 is prime.  If 443 are the first three digits, then the last three digits must total 20, start with a 7 and end with a 4, 6 or 8.  There is only three ways to do this: 758, 776 and 794.  The fifth digit can't be prime, so only 794 is possible.  This gives the first number 443,794.
If the first three digits total 23, start with a 4, 6, 8 or 9, and end with a 3 or 7, then the choices are 887 and 977.  The second digit in 977 is prime, so the only choice is 887.  Ralph checks and finds that 887 is prime.  If the first three numbers are 887 then the last three must start with a 3, end with a 4, 6 or 8 and total 8.  Only 314 is possible, giving the second number 887,314.
When Rex tells Ralph one of the numbers is divisible by 13, Ralph finds that 443,794 = 13 x 34,138.  Since 13 can't be one of the prime factors of the number, the number must be 887,314.
Response:
<think>
Alright, so I have this problem where I need to find all positive integers N that satisfy six conditions. It's a bit complex, but I'll try to break it down step by step.

First, let me list out all the conditions again to make sure I don't miss anything:

1. The sum of the prime factors of N is 1400.
2. Both N-1 and N+1 are the product of exactly five (not necessarily distinct) primes.
3. The union of the sets of prime divisors of N-1, N, and N+1 contains exactly 13 distinct primes.
4. For every prime p dividing N, s(p) is prime. If P is the product of s(p) for all p dividing N, then s(P) is prime, s(N) is prime, and s(N) is the reverse of s(P), and they are not equal.
5. N is written with 2m digits (m ≥ 2). The only prime digits are the two middle digits, d_m and d_{m+1}, and the two-digit number formed by them is prime.
6. The three-digit integer formed by the first three digits of N is prime. Additionally, the sum of its digits, the sum of the sum, and the sum of that sum are all prime.

It's also given that exactly two integers satisfy Conditions 1–6, and exactly one of them is divisible by 13. So, part (a) is to find the two integers satisfying Conditions 1–5, and part (b) is to specify which one isn't divisible by 13.

Let me start by tackling each condition one by one and see how they can help narrow down N.

**Condition 1: Sum of prime factors of N is 1400.**

This means that if N is factored into primes as N = p1^a1 * p2^a2 * ... * pk^ak, then the sum p1 + p2 + ... + pk = 1400. Note that this is the sum without considering multiplicities, so each prime is counted once regardless of its exponent.

**Condition 2: N-1 and N+1 are products of exactly five primes.**

So, both N-1 and N+1 are 5-almost primes. They can be prime powers or products of distinct primes, but the total number of prime factors with multiplicity is five.

**Condition 3: The union of prime divisors of N-1, N, and N+1 has exactly 13 distinct primes.**

This tells me that the total number of unique primes dividing N-1, N, or N+1 is 13. So, if I consider all the primes in the factorizations of N-1, N, and N+1, there are 13 distinct ones.

**Condition 4: For every prime p dividing N, s(p) is prime. Let P be the product of s(p) for all p|N. Then s(P) is prime, s(N) is prime, and s(N) is the reverse of s(P), and they are different.**

This is a bit involved. Let's parse it:

- For each prime p dividing N, the sum of its digits s(p) is prime.
- P is the product of these s(p)s.
- Then, s(P) is prime, s(N) is prime, and s(N) is the reverse of s(P), but not equal to it.

So, s(N) and s(P) are two-digit primes that are reverses of each other.

**Condition 5: N has 2m digits, m ≥ 2. The only prime digits are the two middle digits, d_m and d_{m+1}, and the two-digit number 10d_m + d_{m+1} is prime.**

So, N is a number with even digits, at least four digits. The middle two digits are primes (2,3,5,7), and the number formed by them is prime. Also, all other digits are non-prime (i.e., 0,1,4,6,8,9).

**Condition 6: The first three digits form a prime number. Also, s(d1d2d3), s²(d1d2d3), and s³(d1d2d3) are all prime.**

So, the three-digit number d1d2d3 is prime. Then, the sum of its digits is prime, the sum of the sum is prime, and the sum of that sum is prime.

Alright, now let's think about how to approach this.

First, since N is a number with 2m digits, m ≥ 2, so N is at least a four-digit number. The middle two digits are primes, and the two-digit number they form is prime. So, the middle two digits must be one of the two-digit primes where both digits are prime. Let's list all two-digit primes with both digits prime:

Hint:
The stranded survivors are not particularly great at math, so the first survivor placed four rotten coconuts as aides to help split the counting pile evenly. Each survivor after also uses the rotten coconuts to help calculate how to split the pile evenly despite there being one spare coconut that will be given to the monkey.
Of course, being rotten coconuts, these coconuts are put to the side after all the divisions, as no pirate wants to put them in the pile or their stash of coconuts.
Human Solution:
First, we start with 5^5 coconuts. This is the smallest number that can be divided evenly into fifths, have a fifth removed and the process repeated five times, with no coconuts going to the monkey.
Four of the 5^5 coconuts are rotten and placed aside. When the remaining supply of coconuts is divided into fifths, there will of course be one non-rotten coconut left over to give to the monkey.
After the first person has taken his share, and the monkey has his coconut, we put the four rotten coconuts back with the others to make a pile of 5^4 coconuts. This can be evenly divided by 5. Before making this next division, however, we again put the four rotten coconuts aside so that the division will leave an extra coconut for the monkey.
This procedure - borrowing the rotten coconuts only long enough to see that an even division into fifths can be made, then putting them aside again - is repeated at each division. After the sixth and last division, the rotten coconuts remain on the side, the property of no one.
The rotten coconuts aren't actual coconuts, since they end up the property of no one, but since we see that 5^5 coconuts can be divided neatly with the use of the four rotten coconuts, the answer is 5^5 - 4, or 3121 coconuts.
Alternatively, we can set up a system of equations to solve the problem. For each step, we can establish a system of equations:
F = (N5)/5
N5 = 4(N4)/5 - 1
N4 = 4(N3)/5 - 1
N3 = 4(N2)/5 - 1
N2 = 4(N1)/5 - 1
N1 = 4(N)/5 - 1
F is the final share of coconuts, and N is the initial pile of coconuts. N1 corresponds to the pile after the first survivor was done taking their share, N2 corresponds to the pile after the second survivor was done taking their share, and so on and so forth.
Substitution results in the following equation:
(4^5)N = (5^6)F + (4 * 5^5) - 4^6
or
1024N = 15625F + 8404
Given that N and F must be positive integers, this equation can be solved with brute force or modular arithmetic to yield 3121.

Okay, so I have this problem about coconuts and five castaways. It seems like a classic coconut problem, which I remember usually involves some modular arithmetic and working backwards. Let me try to break it down step by step.

First, the problem says that each night, a different castaway takes a turn dividing the pile into five equal whole-number piles with exactly one coconut left over. Then, they discard that extra coconut, hide one of the five piles, and the remaining four are pushed together to form the next pile. This happens five times, once each night, and in the morning, the remaining pile is divided equally among the five with no remainder. We need to find the smallest possible number of coconuts that could have been in the original pile.

Hmm, okay. So, each time a castaway takes their turn, the pile size changes. Let me try to model this mathematically.

Let’s denote the number of coconuts before each castaway's turn as N. When a castaway divides the pile, they find that N divided by 5 leaves a remainder of 1. So, mathematically, N ≡ 1 mod 5. That means N can be expressed as 5k + 1 for some integer k.

Then, the castaway discards the extra coconut, so the pile becomes 5k. They then hide one of the five equal piles, which is k coconuts, and the remaining four piles are pushed together, forming a new pile of 4k coconuts.

So, each operation transforms the pile from N to 4k, where N = 5k + 1. Therefore, substituting k, we get N = 5*(N') + 1, where N' is the new pile after the castaway's turn. Wait, no, let me think again.

Wait, actually, if N = 5k + 1, then after discarding 1, it's 5k. Then, hiding one pile of k, so the remaining is 4k. So, the next pile is 4k. So, N' = 4k. But since N = 5k + 1, we can express k in terms of N: k = (N - 1)/5. Therefore, N' = 4*(N - 1)/5.

So, the transformation is N' = (4/5)*(N - 1). Hmm, that's a fractional transformation, but since N is congruent to 1 mod 5, (N - 1) is divisible by 5, so N' is an integer.

So, each time, the pile is transformed by N' = (4/5)*(N - 1). So, starting from the original pile, let's call it N0, after the first castaway, it becomes N1 = (4/5)*(N0 - 1). Then, N2 = (4/5)*(N1 - 1), and so on, until after five nights, we have N5, which is divided equally among the five castaways with no remainder. So, N5 must be divisible by 5.

Our goal is to find the smallest N0 such that after five such transformations, N5 is divisible by 5.

This seems like a problem that can be approached by working backwards. That is, starting from the morning pile, which is divisible by 5, and figuring out what the pile must have been each night before each castaway's turn.

Let me try that approach.

Let’s denote N5 as the pile in the morning, which is divisible by 5. Let's say N5 = 5a, where a is an integer.

Now, before the fifth castaway's turn, the pile was N4. After the fifth castaway took their turn, the pile became N5. So, N5 = (4/5)*(N4 - 1). Therefore, N4 can be expressed in terms of N5.

Let me write that equation:

N5 = (4/5)*(N4 - 1)

So, solving for N4:

Multiply both sides by 5: 5*N5 = 4*(N4 - 1)

Then, 5*N5 = 4*N4 - 4

Bring the 4 to the left: 5*N5 + 4 = 4*N4

Divide both sides by 4: N4 = (5*N5 + 4)/4

Since N4 must be an integer, (5*N5 + 4) must be divisible by 4.

Given that N5 is divisible by 5, let's write N5 = 5a, so:

N4 = (5*(5a) + 4)/4 = (25a + 4)/4

So, 25a + 4 must be divisible by 4. Let's see what that implies for a.

25a ≡ 1a mod 4, since 25 divided by 4 is 6 with remainder 1. So, 25a ≡ a mod 4.

Therefore, 25a + 4 ≡ a + 0 mod 4 (since 4 ≡ 0 mod 4). So, 25a + 4 ≡ a mod 4.

We need 25a + 4 ≡ 0 mod 4, so a ≡ 0 mod 4.

Therefore, a must be a multiple of 4. Let's set a = 4b, where b is an integer.

Question:
Problem.

An integer is said to be a palindrome if its base-$10$ representation reads the same from left to right as from right to left.

Determine the unique positive integer $n$ satisfying both of the following conditions:

1. $n$ itself is \emph{not} a palindrome;
2. $n^{3}$ \emph{is} a palindrome.

Give the value of $n$.
Hint: A palindrome is a number that reads the same forward as it does backward.  An example would be 1221. An integer is a number that has no decimal places.  A cube is the result of multiplying a number by itself three times.
Response:
<think>
Okay, so I have this problem where I need to find a unique positive integer n that isn't a palindrome itself, but when I cube it, the result is a palindrome. Hmm, interesting. Let me try to break this down step by step.

First, let me make sure I understand what a palindrome is. A palindrome is a number that reads the same forwards and backwards. For example, 121 is a palindrome because reversing the digits gives the same number. Similarly, 1331 is a palindrome because it reads the same both ways.

So, the problem is asking for a number n that isn't a palindrome, but n³ is. And it's supposed to be unique, so there should be only one such number. Cool, let's dive in.

I think the best approach is to start testing numbers that aren't palindromes and see if their cubes are palindromes. But before I start randomly testing, maybe I can find a pattern or some properties that can help narrow down the candidates.

Let me consider the properties of palindromic numbers. A palindromic number has symmetry in its digits. So, if n³ is a palindrome, then n³ must have this symmetry. But n itself doesn't have to be symmetric.

I wonder if there are any known numbers like this. I recall that 2 is not a palindrome, but 2³ is 8, which is a single-digit number and thus trivially a palindrome. Wait, but 8 is a palindrome, right? So, does that mean 2 is a candidate? Hmm, but 2 is a single-digit number, which is technically a palindrome because it's the same forwards and backwards. Question:
\begin{problem}
A train of constant speed passes a point $P$ on a straight track.  
At the instant the \emph{front} of the train is at $P$, two pedestrians located at $P$ begin walking at the same constant speed:  
one walks in the \emph{same} direction as the train, while the other walks in the \emph{opposite} direction.  
Each pedestrian stops walking precisely when the \emph{back} of the train passes him.  

If the pedestrian walking opposite the train travels $30$ feet and the pedestrian walking with the train travels $45$ feet, determine the length of the train, in feet.
\end{problem}
Hint: Try to get a ratio between the train's speed and the speed of Al and Ben
Human Solution:
The train is 180 feet long.
When the back of the train passes Al, he and Ben have both walked 30 feet, meaning Ben will walk 15 feet more when the train passes him. 30 feet that Al walks plus 45 feet that Ben walks makes 75 feet that the back of the train travels in the same time that Ben walks 15 feet, meaning the train is 5 times as fast as Al and Ben.
In the time it takes Al to walk 30 feet, the front of the train moves 150 feet. This distance plus the 30 feet that Al has walked equals 180 feet.
Response:
<think>
Okay, so I have this problem about a train passing a point P, and two pedestrians starting to walk at the same time the front of the train is at P. One walks in the same direction as the train, and the other walks opposite. Both stop when the back of the train passes them. The pedestrian walking opposite goes 30 feet, and the one walking with goes 45 feet. I need to find the length of the train.

Hmm, let me visualize this. The train is moving at a constant speed, let's call that speed V_train. The pedestrians are walking at the same constant speed, let's say V_ped. Both start walking when the front of the train is at P, and they stop when the back of the train passes them.

So, for the pedestrian walking opposite to the train, he's moving against the direction of the train. The train is moving towards him, so the relative speed between the train and him is V_train + V_ped. Because they're moving towards each other, their relative speed adds up.

On the other hand, the pedestrian walking in the same direction as the train is moving away from the train, but the train is catching up to him. So the relative speed here is V_train - V_ped. Since the train is faster, it will eventually pass him.

Both pedestrians start at the same time, and they stop when the back of the train passes them. So, the time it takes for the back of the train to reach each pedestrian is different because their relative speeds are different.

Let me denote the length of the train as L. That's what we need to find.

For the pedestrian walking opposite (let's call him Ped A), the distance he covers until the back of the train passes him is 30 feet. Similarly, the pedestrian walking in the same direction (Ped B) covers 45 feet.

Wait, actually, the distance each pedestrian covers is the distance they walk until the back of the train passes them. So, for Ped A, moving opposite, the back of the train has to cover the entire length of the train plus the distance Ped A has walked. Similarly, for Ped B, moving in the same direction, the back of the train has to cover the entire length of the train minus the distance Ped B has walked, because Ped B is moving away.

Wait, no, maybe I need to think in terms of time. Let me denote T_A as the time it takes for the back of the train to pass Ped A, and T_B as the time for the back of the train to pass Ped B.

For Ped A, moving opposite, the distance between the front of the train and Ped A is initially zero because the front is at P when they start. But the back of the train is L feet behind the front. So, when the front is at P, the back is L feet behind P. So, when the front starts moving forward, the back is approaching Ped A, who is moving towards the train.

Wait, no. At the initial moment, the front is at P, so the back is L feet behind P. So, Ped A is at P, and the back of the train is L feet behind P. So, when the train starts moving forward, the back of the train is moving towards P, but Ped A is moving away from P in the opposite direction.

Wait, no, the train is moving in one direction, say to the right. So, the front is at P, moving right. The back is L feet to the left of P. Ped A is at P, starts walking left (opposite direction). So, the back of the train is moving right towards P, while Ped A is moving left away from P.

So, the distance between the back of the train and Ped A is initially L feet. But as time passes, the back of the train moves right at speed V_train, and Ped A moves left at speed V_ped. So, the distance between them decreases at a rate of V_train + V_ped. So, the time it takes for the back of the train to reach Ped A is the initial distance divided by their relative speed: T_A = L / (V_train + V_ped).

Similarly, for Ped B, who is walking in the same direction as the train. The front of the train is at P, moving right. The back is L feet behind, so at position P - L. Ped B starts at P and walks right at speed V_ped. The back of the train is moving right at V_train, so the distance between the back of the train and Ped B is initially L feet. But since both are moving in the same direction, the relative speed is V_train - V_ped. So, the time it takes for the back of the train to catch up to Ped B is T_B = L / (V_train - V_ped).

Now, during these times T_A and T_B, each pedestrian is walking their respective distances. So, for Ped A, distance walked is V_ped * T_A = 30 feet. Similarly, for Ped B, distance walked is V_ped * T_B = 45 feet.

So, let's write the equations:

For Ped A:
V_ped * T_A = 30
But T_A = L / (V_train + V_ped)
So, V_ped * (L / (V_train + V_ped)) = 30

For Ped B:
V_ped * T_B = 45
But T_B = L / (V_train - V_ped)
So, V_ped * (L / (V_train - V_ped)) = 45

So, now we have two equations:

1) (V_ped * L) / (V_train + V_ped) = 30
2) (V_ped * L) / (V_train - V_ped) = 45

Let me denote V_ped as v and V_train as u for simplicity.

So, equation 1: (v * L) / (u + v) = 30
Equation 2: (v * L) / (u - v) = 45

We can write these as:

1) vL = 30(u + v)
2) vL = 45(u - v)

Since both equal vL, we can set them equal to each other:

30(u + v) = 45(u - v)

Let me solve this equation:

30u + 30v = 45u - 45v
Bring like terms together:

30u - 45u + 30v + 45v = 0
-15u + 75v = 0
Divide both sides by -15:

u - 5v = 0
So, u = 5v

So, the speed of the train is 5 times the speed of the pedestrians.

Now, let's substitute u = 5v into one of the equations to find L.

Let's take equation 1:

vL = 30(u + v) = 30(5v + v) = 30(6v) = 180v

So, vL = 180v

Divide both sides by v (assuming v ≠ 0, which it isn't because they are walking):

L = 180 feet

Wait, that seems straightforward. Let me check with equation 2:

vL = 45(u - v) = 45(5v - v) = 45(4v) = 180v

So, same result, L = 180 feet.

So, the length of the train is 180 feet.

Wait, let me just make sure I didn't make a mistake in the relative speeds.

For Ped A, moving opposite, the relative speed is u + v, so time is L / (u + v). Distance walked is v * T = v * (L / (u + v)) = 30.

For Ped B, moving same direction, relative speed is u - v, so time is L / (u - v). Distance walked is v * (L / (u - v)) = 45.

Then, setting up the equations:

(vL)/(u + v) = 30

(vL)/(u - v) = 45

Then, solving gives u = 5v, and substituting back gives L = 180.

Yes, that seems correct.

**Final Answer**
The length of the train is \boxed{180} feet.
</think>

Let the speed of the train be \( V_{\text{train}} \) and the speed of each pedestrian be \( V_{\text{ped}} \). The length of the train is \( L \).

For the pedestrian walking opposite to the train (Ped A), the relative speed between the train and the pedestrian is \( V_{\text{train}} + V_{\text{ped}} \). The time it takes for the back of the train to pass Ped A is \( \frac{L}{V_{\text{train}} + V_{\text{ped}}} \). The distance Ped A walks is \( V_{\text{ped}} \times \frac{L}{V_{\text{train}} + V_{\text{ped}}} = 30 \) feet. This gives us the equation:
\[
\frac{V_{\text{ped}} \cdot L}{V_{\text{train}} + V_{\text{ped}}} = 30
\]

For the pedestrian walking in the same direction as the train (Ped B), the relative speed between the train and the pedestrian is \( V_{\text{train}} - V_{\text{ped}} \). The time it takes for the back of the train to pass Ped B is \( \frac{L}{V_{\text{train}} - V_{\text{ped}}} \). The distance Ped B walks is \( V_{\text{ped}} \times \frac{L}{V_{\text{train}} - V_{\text{ped}}} = 45 \) feet. This gives us the equation:
\[
\frac{V_{\text{ped}} \cdot L}{V_{\text{train}} - V_{\text{ped}}} = 45
\]

We now have two equations:
1. \(\frac{V_{\text{ped}} \cdot L}{V_{\text{train}} + V_{\text{ped}}} = 30\)
2. \(\frac{V_{\text{ped}} \cdot L}{V_{\text{train}} - V_{\text{ped}}} = 45\)

Let \( V_{\text{ped}} = v \) and \( V_{\text{train}} = u \). The equations become:
1. \(\frac{v \cdot L}{u + v} = 30\)
2. \(\frac{v \cdot L}{u - v} = 45\)

From these, we can write:
1. \( vL = 30(u + v) \)
2. \( vL = 45(u - v) \)

Setting the right-hand sides equal to each other:
\[
30(u + v) = 45(u - v)
\]

Solving for \( u \) and \( v \):
\[
30u + 30v = 45u - 45v
\]
\[
-15u + 75v = 0
\]
\[
u = 5v
\]

Substituting \( u = 5v \) back into the first equation:
\[
vL = 30(5v + v)
\]
\[
vL = 180v
\]
\[
L = 180
\]

Thus, the length of the train is \(\boxed{180}\) feet.

Question:
\[
\textbf{Swap–Time Problem}
\]

On an ideal \(12\)-hour analog clock the minute hand makes one revolution every \(60\) minutes, while the hour hand makes one revolution every \(12\) hours.  
Define a \emph{Swap Time} to be a time at which exchanging the positions of the hour hand and the minute hand still yields a configuration that occurs at some (possibly different) valid time on the same clock.

\begin{enumerate}
    \item[(a)]  Determine every Swap Time that occurs after \(1{:}00{:}00.00\) and before \(2{:}00{:}00.00\).  
    Express each answer in the form 
    \[
        1{:}\!MM{:}SS. \! SS,
    \]
    rounded to the nearest hundredth of a second.

    \item[(b)]  How many Swap Times occur during one complete \(12\)-hour cycle (from \(12{:}00\) up to, but not including, the next \(12{:}00\))?
\end{enumerate}

(Ignore any distinction between a.m. and p.m.)
Hint: Represent the minute hand and hour hand's paths with equations and notice that the fraction the minute hand is through th whole circle must be equivalent to eh fraction of the hour hand between two hour markers
Human Solution:
A) Noon is a Swap Time. Since both hands are pointing at 12, swapping them generates the exact same valid time. In fact, all eleven times when the hands point in the exact same
direction are Swap Times.
B) Let's do some math.
Rule 1) For a valid time, the fraction of the minute hand's progress around the full circle must be equal to the fraction of the hour hand's progress between two numbers. For example, when the minute hand points at the 6, halfway around the clock, the hour hand must be pointed halfway between two numbers.
Rule 2) For a Swap Time, it must also be true that the fraction of the progress of the hour hand around the full circle is equal to the fraction of the progress of the minute hand between two numbers.
Let H = hour hand angle in degrees
Let M = minute hand angle in degrees
Note that there are 360/12 = 30 degrees between numbers on the clock.
Rule 1
H = <angle to number> + <angle past number>
H = 30 * i + <minute hand progress> / 30 : i = 0, 1, 2,..., 11
H = 30 * i + (M / 360) / 30
H = 30 * i + M / 12
Rule 2
M = 30 * j + H / 12 : j = 0, 1, 2,..., 11
Substituting for H:
M = 30 * j + (30 * i + M / 12) / 12
M = 30 * j + 5 * i / 2 + M / 144
143 * M / 144 = 30 * j + 5 * i / 2
M = 144 / 143 * (30 * j + 5 * i / 2) : i = 0,1,2,...,11 j = 0,1,2,...,11
Let s be the number of seconds that have elapsed in the current hour.
Since the minute hand moves at 0.1 degrees per second (360 deg / 3600 s), s = 10 * M
s = 10 * [144 / 143 * (30 * j + 5 * i / 2)] : i = 0,1,2,...,11 j = 0,1,2,...,11
To find all Swap Times between 1:00 and 2:00, set i = 1 and check all values of j.
j = 0, s = 25.17482517, time = 1:00:25.17
j = 1, s = 327.2727273, time = 1:05:27.27
Remaining swap times are
1:10:29.37
1:15:31.47
1:20:33.57
1:25:35.66
1:30:37.76
1:35:39.86
1:40:41.96
1:45:44.06
1:50:46.15
1:55:48.25
Swap Time occur every 12 * 3600 / 143 = 302.0979 seconds.
There are 143 total swap times.
Response:
<think>
Okay, so I have this problem about Swap Times on an analog clock. It's part (a) and (b). Let me try to understand what a Swap Time is. The problem says that a Swap Time is when you can exchange the positions of the hour and minute hands, and the resulting configuration is a valid time on the clock. So, if at time T, swapping the hour and minute hands gives another valid time T', then T is a Swap Time.

First, I need to figure out how to model the positions of the hour and minute hands mathematically. I know that the minute hand moves 360 degrees in 60 minutes, so that's 6 degrees per minute. The hour hand moves 360 degrees in 12 hours, which is 30 degrees per hour, or 0.5 degrees per minute.

Let me denote the time as H hours, M minutes, and S seconds. But since we're dealing with a 12-hour clock, H is between 1 and 12. However, in part (a), we're specifically looking between 1:00:00.00 and 2:00:00.00, so H is 1, and M and S vary.

Let me convert everything into minutes and seconds for easier calculations. Let's let t be the number of minutes after 1:00:00.00. So, t = M + S/60, where M is minutes and S is seconds. Question:
Let  

• $T$ be the current age (in years) of Tommy, the oldest child,  
• $I$ be the current age of Timmy,  
• $A$ be the current age of Tammy,  
• $R$ be the current age of Tracey,  
• $Y$ be the current age of Tony, the youngest child, and  
• $M$ be the current age of their mother.  

Assume all ages are positive integers and 
\[
T > I > A > R > Y>0 .
\]

The following conditions are known.  

1.  At present, Tammy is three times as old as Timmy was when Tony was born:
   \[
   A = 3\,(I-Y).
   \]

2.  When Tony was born (that is, $Y$ years ago) the mother’s age was a positive integer that was divisible by each of her children’s ages at that time:
   \[
   T-Y,\; I-Y,\; A-Y,\; R-Y \;\Big| \; M-Y .
   \]

3.  Except for the year of Tony’s birth, the only other year in which more than two of the children’s ages simultaneously divided the mother’s age was the year in which  
   Tracey’s age equaled one-half of Tammy’s current age, i.e.\ the year when Tracey was $\dfrac{A}{2}$ years old.

4.  When the mother turns $50$, Tony will be exactly as old as the mother was when Tommy was born:
   \[
   50-\bigl(M-Y\bigr)=M-T .
   \]

Determine the current ages $T, I, A, R, Y,$ and $M$.
Human Solution:
Tommy is 23, Timmy is 19, Tammy is 18, Tracey is 16, Tony is 13 and Mum is 43.
Solution:
x = Mum's age when she gave birth to Tommy = Tony's age when Mum turns 50;
y = Tommy's age when Tony was born
z = Mum's age when Tony was born
From Tammy's last statement, 2x + y = 50 and it can be deduced that x = z - y, where y is a factor of z.  By combining the two equations you get 2z = 50 + y The only possible solutions for that equation so that y is also a factor of z are (z = 26, y = 2) and (z = 30, y = 10).  Only 30 has four or more factors, so Mum was 30 and Tommy was 10 when Tony was born.
This means that of the remaining factors of 30, Timmy was 6, 5 or 3, Tammy was 5, 3 or 2 and Tracey was 3, 2 or 1.  This makes Tammy 18, 15 or 9 now.  The only other time where the ages of more than two of the children were factors of Mum's age was when Tracey was half what Tammy is now, so Tammy must be 18 now.
In the second multiple-factors-of-Mum's-age year, Tracey was therefore 9.  When Tony was born, Tracey was either 3, 2 or 1, giving possible time differences of 6, 7 or 8 years, which correspond to Tony's age in the second multiple-factors-of-Mum's-age year.  It also means Mum was 36, 37 or 38 that year.  37 is prime and 38 has factors of 1, 2 and 19, and as Tony was at least 6, it means that Mum must have been 36 that year.
Going back to when Tony was born we have that Mum was 30, Tommy was 10, Timmy was 6, Tracey was 3, and as the middle child Tammy must have been 5.  If Tammy is 18 now then Tony is 13, Tracey is 16, Timmy is 19, Tommy is 23 and Mum is 43.

Question:
\[
\textbf{Problem.}\qquad
\begin{aligned}
&\text{Four sisters—Alice, Barbara, Cheryl, and Denise—were married on June }30\text{ in four}\\[-2pt]
&\text{consecutive years.  Alice was married first, three years ago; Barbara two years ago;}\\[-2pt]
&\text{Cheryl one year ago; and Denise this year.  Each sister’s birthday occurs before}\\[-2pt]
&\text{June }30,\text{ so that her age in \emph{whole years} on her wedding day is an integer.}
\end{aligned}
\]

Let  
\[
A,\;B,\;C,\;D
\]
denote, respectively, the current ages (in years) of Alice, Barbara, Cheryl, and Denise on the day of Denise’s wedding (the most recent wedding).  

For any positive integer \(n\) let  
\[
s(n)=\text{(sum of the decimal digits of }n).
\]

On the day of each wedding, the bride’s age was equal to the sum of the decimal digits of the ages of her three sisters \emph{at that moment}.  Hence

\[
\begin{aligned}
D &= s(A)+s(B)+s(C),\\[2pt]
C-1 &= s(A-1)+s(B-1)+s(D-1),\\[2pt]
B-2 &= s(A-2)+s(C-2)+s(D-2),\\[2pt]
A-3 &= s(B-3)+s(C-3)+s(D-3).
\end{aligned}
\]

Determine the ordered quadruple \((A,B,C,D)\) of positive integers that satisfies all four equations.
Hint:
1. Any non-negative integer is congruent to the sum of its digits, mod 9.  (They have the same remainder when divided by 9.)
2. Each daughter was between 17 and 33 at the time of her wedding.
Human Solution:
Alice is 27, Barbara is 28, Cheryl is 20, and Denise is 21, 21 = 2+7+2+8+2+0.
A year ago, they were 26, 27, 19, and 20, 19 = 2+6+2+7+2+0.
Two years ago, they were 25, 26, 18, and 19, 26 = 2+5+1+8+1+9.
Three years ago, they were 24, 25, 17, and 18, 24 = 2+5+1+7+1+8.
You can solve this one by trial and error (particularly with the hint), but you can also use the fact that any non-negative integer is congruent to the sum of its digits, mod 9.  If a, b, c, and d are the present ages of the four women, that gives us four linear congruences:
d = a + b + c (mod 9)
c-1 = (a-1)+(b-1)+(d-1) (mod 9)
b-2 = (a-2)+(c-2)+(d-2) (mod 9)
a-3 = (b-3)+(c-3)+(d-3) (mod 9).
Solving for the four variables, we get: a=0, b=1, c=2, d=3 (all mod 9).  It remains to find four integers congruent to these numbers that will satisfy the digit addition property.   If you use the age restriction in the hint, you can omit some of the following analysis, but I present it here in full to show that the solution is truly unique even without the hint.
If we go back 3 years to Alice's wedding, we have: a-3=6, b-3=7, c-3=8, and d-3=9 (mod 9).  Now all numbers less than 79 that are congruent to 7 also have a digit sum of 7, and likewise numbers congruent to 8 less than 89 have a digit sum of 8, and numbers congruent to 9 (except 0) less than 99 have a digit sum of 9.   We can rule out  such high ages, because each woman must have a turn being the sum of her sister's ages' digits, and the maximum sum of digits for three ages less than 199 is 54 (for 99, 99, and 99).  Likewise, we can rule out zero as a valid age for Denise three years ago, because she needs to have an age now that can be the sum of the digits of three other valid ages.  So Alice three years ago must have been 7+8+9=24, making her 27 now.
Now go back 2 years to Barbara's wedding.  Alice we now know was 25.  Cheryl's age was congruent to 9 (mod 9), so she must have had a digit sum of 9.  Denise's age was congruent to 1 (mod 9), so she must have had a digit sum of 10 unless she was 10 years old herself (we have previously ruled out 1 as a valid age). But if Denise was 10, then Barbara would have been 17 two years ago, and this year Alice and Barbara together would be contributing 2+7+1+9 = 19 years to Denise's age, contradicting the assumption that she was 10 two years ago.  So Denise had a digit sum of 10 two years ago, and Barbara was therefore 2+5+9+10=26 at the time of her wedding, hence 28 now.
Now consider Cheryl's wedding last year.  Alice was 26 and Barbara was 27.  Denise's age was congruent to 2 (mod 9), so she must have had a digit sum of either 2 or 11.  If it was 11, then Cheryl would have been 11+2+6+2+7=28 then, making her 29 now.  But then Denise would have to be 2+7+2+8+2+9=30 now to Alice's 27, contradicting the information that Alice was her older sister.  So Denise's digit sum must have been 2 last year, making Cheryl 19 then, and Denise 21 now.

Question:
\[
\textbf{Problem.}
\]
Let \(S\) and \(T\) be positive integers, each at most \(1\,000\,000\), representing the numbers of dollars owned by Sandy and Sue, respectively.  
Suppose the following two conditions hold.

1.  There exists a positive integer \(d\) such that
\[
T-d = S+d
\quad\text{and}\quad
T+d = 2(S-d).
\]

2.  Write \(T\) in decimal form as \(T = a\cdot10^{k}+b\), where \(a\in\{1,2,\dots,9\}\) is its leading digit and \(0\le b<10^{k}\).  
   Moving this leading digit to the right end produces Sandy’s amount:
\[
S = 10b+a.
\]

Determine the ordered pair \((S,T)\).
Hint: First get the ratio, then get their amount.
Human Solution:
Let X and Y be Sandy's and Sue's amounts of money, respectively. Let Z be the number of dollars in Sandy's statement.
Then X+Z=Y-Z and 2(X-Z)=Y+Z. Solving this we get X=5Z and Y=7Z.
According to Sue's statement, let A be the first digit of Sue's wealth, B be the remaining digits, and n be the number of digits, then Y=A*10^(n-1)+B and X=10B+A.
7X=5Y
7*(10B+A)=5*(A*10^(n-1)+B)
(5*10^(n-1)-7)A=65B
Since 65B is divisible by 5 and 5*10^(n-1)-7 is not, A must equal 5. We get:
5*10^(n-1)-7=13B
The least value of n such that 5*10^(n-1)-7 is a multiple of 13 is 6:
499993=38461*13
The next is 12, which makes them have more than 1 million dollars. Hence n=6 and B=38461.
Therefore, Sandy has 384615 dollars and Sue has 538461 dollars.
Response:
<think>
Okay, so I have this problem where I need to find two positive integers, S and T, each at most 1,000,000. They represent the amounts of money Sandy and Sue have, respectively. There are two conditions given, and I need to figure out what S and T are based on those conditions.

Let me start by breaking down the problem step by step. First, let's look at the two conditions separately and then see how they can be combined.

**Condition 1:**
There exists a positive integer d such that:
1. T - d = S + d
2. T + d = 2(S - d)

Hmm, okay. So, we have two equations here involving T, S, and d. Let me write them down:

1. T - d = S + d
2. T + d = 2(S - d)

I can try to solve these equations simultaneously to find a relationship between S and T.

Starting with the first equation:
T - d = S + d
Let me rearrange this to express T in terms of S and d:
T = S + d + d
T = S + 2d

So, equation 1 gives me T = S + 2d.

Now, moving on to the second equation:
T + d = 2(S - d)
Let me expand the right side:
T + d = 2S - 2d

Now, let's substitute T from equation 1 into this equation. Since T = S + 2d, plugging that in:
(S + 2d) + d = 2S - 2d
Simplify the left side:
S + 3d = 2S - 2d

Now, let's bring all terms to one side to solve for S and d:
S + 3d - 2S + 2d = 0
Combine like terms:
(-S) + 5d = 0
Which simplifies to:
S = 5d

So, from condition 1, we have S = 5d and T = S + 2d = 5d + 2d = 7d.

Therefore, T is 7 times d, and S is 5 times d. So, S and T are multiples of 5 and 7 respectively, scaled by the same positive integer d.

**Condition 2:**
Now, moving on to the second condition. It says that if we write T in decimal form as T = a·10^k + b, where a is the leading digit (from 1 to 9) and b is the remaining number (0 ≤ b < 10^k). Then, moving this leading digit to the right end gives Sandy’s amount S, which is 10b + a.

So, in other words, if T is a number like a followed by some digits b, then S is the number formed by moving a to the end of b. For example, if T was 1234, then a=1, b=234, and S would be 2341.

Mathematically, this can be written as:
T = a·10^k + b
S = 10b + a

Given that S and T are related by S = 5d and T = 7d, we can set up equations using this condition.

So, let's write down the equations:

1. T = a·10^k + b
2. S = 10b + a

But we also know from condition 1 that S = 5d and T = 7d. So, substituting S and T:

1. 7d = a·10^k + b
2. 5d = 10b + a

So now, we have two equations:

7d = a·10^k + b  ...(1)
5d = 10b + a     ...(2)

Our goal is to find integers d, a, b, and k such that these equations hold, with the constraints that a is between 1 and 9, and b is less than 10^k.

Let me try to express b from equation (2) and substitute into equation (1).

From equation (2):
5d = 10b + a
Let me solve for b:
10b = 5d - a

Given the problem, we need to determine the ordered pair \((S, T)\) where \(S\) and \(T\) are positive integers each at most 1,000,000, satisfying two conditions.

**Condition 1:**

2. \(T + d = 2(S - d)\)

From these equations, we derive:
1. \(T = S + 2d\)
2. Substituting \(T\) into the second equation, we get \(S = 5d\) and \(T = 7d\).

**Condition 2:**
Write \(T\) in decimal form as \(T = a \cdot 10^k + b\), where \(a\) is the leading digit and \(0 \le b < 10^k\). Moving the leading digit \(a\) to the end produces \(S = 10b + a\).

We express \(T\) and \(S\) as:
1. \(7d = a \cdot 10^k + b\)
2. \(5d = 10b + a\)

From these, we find:
1. \(b = \frac{5d - a}{10}\)
2. Substituting \(b\) into the first equation, we get \(65d = a(10^{k+1} - 1)\).

Since \(a\) must be a single digit (1-9) and \(10^{k+1} - 1\) must be divisible by 13, we find \(a = 5\) and \(k = 5\). This gives:

2. \(S = 5d = 384615\)
3. \(T = 7d = 538461\)

Thus, the ordered pair is \(\boxed{(384615, 538461)}\).

Question:
\[
\textbf{Problem.}\quad
\text{Find the least positive integer } N \text{ that satisfies}
\]
\[
N \equiv 1 \pmod m \qquad \text{for every integer } m \text{ with } 2 \le m \le 10,
\]
\[
N \equiv 0 \pmod{11}.
\]
\[
\text{What is } N?
\]
Hint: Recall that if n is a prime number, (n-1)!+1 is divisible by n.
Human Solution:
10!+1=3628801 eggs. This is an answer, but not the minimum.
The least common multiple of 1 to 11 is 27720.
3628801=27720*130+25201.
Therefore, the old lady had at least 25201 eggs.

Alright, let's start by understanding what the problem is asking. I need to find the smallest positive integer N such that when I divide N by any number m from 2 to 10, the remainder is 1 each time. Additionally, when I divide N by 11, there should be no remainder; in other words, N should be a multiple of 11.

So, translating the first condition into mathematical terms, for each m in {2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10}, we have:
N ≡ 1 mod m
Which means N = k*m + 1 for some integer k.

And the second condition is:
N ≡ 0 mod 11
Which means N = 11*l for some integer l.

So, N has to satisfy both these conditions. My goal is to find the smallest such N.

I think the key here is to find a number that is 1 more than a multiple of each m from 2 to 10 and also a multiple of 11. So, maybe I can find the least common multiple (LCM) of the numbers from 2 to 10 and then add 1 to it. But wait, let me think about that.

If I take the LCM of 2 through 10, that would give me the smallest number that is a multiple of each of these numbers. Then, adding 1 would make it so that when divided by any of these numbers, the remainder is 1. That makes sense because if LCM is divisible by each m, then LCM + 1 would leave a remainder of 1 when divided by each m.

So, let me calculate the LCM of numbers from 2 to 10. To find the LCM, I need to factor each number into its prime factors:

2 = 2
3 = 3
4 = 2²
5 = 5
6 = 2 * 3
7 = 7
8 = 2³
9 = 3²
10 = 2 * 5

The LCM is the product of the highest powers of all primes present. So, the primes here are 2, 3, 5, 7.

the highest power of 3 is 3² (from 9),
the highest power of 5 is 5¹,

So, LCM = 2³ * 3² * 5 * 7 = 8 * 9 * 5 * 7.

So, the LCM of numbers from 2 to 10 is 2520. Therefore, the number N we're looking for is of the form 2520*k + 1, where k is a positive integer.

But we also have the condition that N must be divisible by 11. So, N = 2520*k + 1 must be congruent to 0 mod 11. In other words:

But since -1 mod 11 is the same as 10 mod 11, we can write:

Now, I need to find the smallest positive integer k such that this congruence holds. To do that, I can first find 2520 mod 11, and then solve for k.

1*k ≡ 10 mod 11

Which simplifies to:

k ≡ 10 mod 11

So, the smallest positive integer k that satisfies this is k=10.

To find the least positive integer \( N \) that satisfies the given conditions, we need to ensure that \( N \equiv 1 \pmod{m} \) for every integer \( m \) from 2 to 10, and \( N \equiv 0 \pmod{11} \).

First, we recognize that \( N \) must be 1 more than a multiple of the least common multiple (LCM) of the numbers from 2 to 10. The LCM of these numbers is calculated as follows:

- Prime factorization of each number:
  - 2 = 2
  - 3 = 3
  - 4 = 2²
  - 5 = 5
  - 6 = 2 * 3
  - 7 = 7
  - 8 = 2³
  - 9 = 3²
  - 10 = 2 * 5

- The LCM is the product of the highest powers of all primes present:
  - LCM = 2³ * 3² * 5 * 7 = 8 * 9 * 5 * 7 = 2520

Thus, \( N \) must be of the form \( 2520k + 1 \) for some integer \( k \).

Next, we need \( N \) to be divisible by 11. Therefore, we solve the congruence:
\[ 2520k + 1 \equiv 0 \pmod{11} \]

Calculating \( 2520 \mod 11 \):
- \( 2520 \div 11 = 229 \) remainder 1, so \( 2520 \equiv 1 \pmod{11} \).

This simplifies the congruence to:
\[ k + 1 \equiv 0 \pmod{11} \]
\[ k \equiv -1 \pmod{11} \]
\[ k \equiv 10 \pmod{11} \]

The smallest positive integer \( k \) is 10. Substituting \( k = 10 \) into the expression for \( N \):
\[ N = 2520 \times 10 + 1 = 25201 \]

Thus, the least positive integer \( N \) that satisfies both conditions is \(\boxed{25201}\).

Question:
\[
\textbf{Problem.}\;
\]
A solid sphere is pierced by drilling a straight cylindrical hole whose axis passes through the center of the sphere.  
The hole has length \(6\text{ cm}\) (the distance between the two circular openings).  
Return the volume of the remaining solid in the form \(k\pi\), for some positive real number \(k\).
Hint:
for a hard solution:
The sphere's diameter (2r) must be the same as the length of the cylinder (H) plus the height of the two caps (2h), so 2r=H+2h.
A right-angled triangle is formed by the radius of the cylinder (R) and half the height of the cylinder (H/2), with the radius of the sphere (r) forming the hypotenuse. Using Pythagoras, R^2+(H/2)^2=r^2.
Hint for an easy solution:
Assume there is a real answer. Therefore, the answer does not depend on the radius of the hole (R). Use whatever value is easiest.
Human Solution:
The volume is exactly 36Pi cm^3 (about 113.1 cm^3).
Hard solution:
The sphere's diameter (2r) must be the same as the length of the cylinder (H) plus the height of the two caps (2h), so 2r=H+2h.
Thus, 2h=2r-H and H=6, so 2h=2r-6 or simply h=r-3.
A right-angled triangle is formed by the radius of the cylinder (R) and half the height of the cylinder (H/2), with the radius of the sphere (r) forming the hypotenuse. Using Pythagoras: R^2+(H/2)^2=r^2.
Thus, R^2=r^2-(H/2)^2 and H=6, so R^2=r^2-9.
Volume of cap = (1/6)Pi(3R^2+h^2)h
(replace R^2 and h with values computed above)
= (1/6)Pi(3(r^2-9)+(r-3)^2)(r-3)
= (1/6)Pi(3r^2-27+r^2-6r+9)(r-3)
= (1/6)Pi(4r^2-6r-18)(r-3)
= (1/6)Pi(4r^3-6r^2-18r-12r^2+18r+54)
= (1/6)Pi(4r^3-18r^2+54)
= (2/3)Pi(r^3)-3Pi(r^2)+9Pi
Volume of cylinder = Pi(R^2)H
(replace R^2 with value computed above, and H with given value of 6)
= Pi(r^2-9)6
= 6Pi(r^2)-54Pi
Volume of sphere remaining = sphere - 2 caps - cylinder
= [ (4/3)Pi(r^3) ] - [ 2 ((2/3)Pi(r^3)-3Pi(r^2)+9Pi) ] - [ 6Pi(r^2)-54Pi ]
= [ (4/3)Pi(r^3) ] - [ (4/3)Pi(r^3)-6Pi(r^2)+18Pi ] - [ 6Pi(r^2) - 54Pi ]
= (4/3)Pi(r^3) - (4/3)Pi(r^3) + 6Pi(r^2) - 18Pi - 6Pi(r^2) + 54Pi
= 36Pi
Easy solution:
Assume the hole is infinitely small (i.e. a radius of 0). Then, the volume of the cylinder (and the volume of the caps) is 0. The height of the cap is 0, so the radius of the sphere (r) is 3cm (half of the length of the cylindrical hole). Thus:
Volume of sphere remaining = sphere - 2 caps - cylinder
= (4/3)Pi(r^3) - 0 - 0
= (4/3)Pi(3^3)
= 36Pi
